'By now, you probably think your opinion of Goldman Sachs and its swarm of Wall Street allies has rock-bottomed at raw loathing. You're wrong. There's more. It turns out that the most destructive of all their recent acts has barely been discussed at all. Here's the rest. This is the story of how some of the richest people in the world – Goldman, Deutsche Bank, the traders at Merrill Lynch, and more – have caused the starvation of some of the poorest people in the world.'
 
 
 
 
 
 Johann Hari: How Goldman gambled on starvation - Johann Hari, Commentators - The Independent
When one hears the words "Goldman Sachs" one assumes class warfare against the very poorest.

post_info.post_title: That merely goes without saying, gansao...

When one hears the words "Goldman Sachs" one assumes class warfare against the very poorest.

 
 I'm starting to realise that you may be right about them...

Gansoa! Do you have a fever? Are you yourself?
 
 I'm quite concerned!

Gansoa! Do you have a fever? Are you yourself?
 
 I'm quite concerned!

 
 I'm fine thank you!
 When I read this I thought of your posts about Goldman Sachs.. hence the thread.
 You seem to have hit it on the nail about them..
 I can remember seeing on the news that world food prices had spiked and that the cause was world demand and the changing tastes of a more affluent China and India.
 Little did I know that the main cause was speculation...
 Scary stuff...

The article is pretty good. I think they should extend bans to a lot of "derivatives" and hedge funds. It has become nothing more than educated gambling. 
 
 Good thing the past two presidents have done nothing to solve this! Instead we try to pass worthless regulations that just end up hurting smaller companies with benefits going to the big companies who gain barriers to entry :) Simone's all for it.
